Do we have to ask user for isDiscrete? We can implement this feature basing on keys send in json 'NumericThresholds' means numeric 'DiscreteTriggers' means discrete if both are present we report error.

We can even remove isDiscrete from dbus api.

You are right. As this and most other properties are not required per spec, I decided to relax some parsing and validation rules. If we can deduce the value from other fields - it is OK. But if user provides optional value and it will be incompatible with other value then I will treat it as error. Examples: 
- 'MetricType' is set to 'Discrete' but 'NumericThresholds' was passed. 
- 'MetricType' is set to 'Numeric' but "DiscreteTriggers' or 'DiscreteTriggerCondition' were passed
- 'DiscreteTriggerCondition' is set to 'Specified' but 'DiscreteTriggers' is an empty array or was not passed.
- 'DiscreteTriggerCondition' is set to 'Changed' but 'DiscreteTriggers' is passed and is not an empty array
Done

Class which performs actions in destructor probably won't be accepted in bmcweb.

Sad thing is that unless there will be major rework in sensors.hpp this seem to be only way that will work.
I was using MetricReportDefinition POST method as an example here, so it won't be such first use case.
After some though, I decided to remove this class.

asyncResp = asyncResp

This way you can avoid one copy
Done
nit: Shouldn't that be Triggers in the call name, i.e.: 'requestRoutesTriggers'?
Changed to TriggersCollection, as POST is used on this schema.
Please don't.  What's there runs faster and uses less memory.
I agree with Ed Tanous, this one runs much faster and there is crashes when id is huge.
I think there is nothing to add here, I will mark this discussion as 'resolved'.
Very complicated as for mapping of single relation, cannot it be simplified?

Yeah, the more I think about it, the more I realize this solution is overcomplicated. There is big chance that in the whole lifetime of redfish and telemetry, this might be the only action to require conversion, so simple 'if' will be enough.
Done
Function seems not to be used.

I know that you are currently working on GET functionality in Trigger schema, so this would be definitely useful here. But as I decided to drop bimap solution, I will remove this function and leave this conversion for you to make.
Variable not used, can its name be hidden from access?
There is no way to filter out structural binding.
Maybe you could give an underscore '_' a try, putting it in place where unused variable occurs within the binding? I believe I noticed a similar solution in the bmcweb code.
Done
Maybe you could also reserve capacity for this vector?
Done
It that needed? In the lambda there is one return of function giving back std:string. Compiler should deduce this one.
Done
It is inside of telemetry namespace, can the namespace scope prefixing be neglected here?
Done
The function containing this macro call is named 'requestRoutesTrigger'. Maybe renaming it into 'requestRoutesTriggersCollection' would be more accurate?
Done

I realize this is something that's already here, but this kind of business logic checking needs to be moved into the telemetry daemon, otherwise, code like this gets duplicated all over the system.


one thing that's interesting here, and something I overlooked initially is that generally ID is not set by the user, so in terms of redfish compliance, this might not be required at all.  Most rest implementations tend to only allow ID for a PUT style change, which Redfish doesn't really define.  Is that something you've considered?

I suspect at a minimum we should make ID optional.

You are right. While this change requires slight modification of telemetry backend, it was worth it and made a lot of sense.

I would leave id as optional, so client can pass his own value.

> You are right. While this change requires slight modification of telemetry backend, it was worth it and made a lot of sense.
> 
> I would leave id as optional, so client can pass his own value.

We should look at the redfish spec for what it allows.  I'm not sure it allows selecting IDs for new POSTs, because that would imply a specific implementation of URIs.  For example, other Redfish instances use a GUID for ID, so the client would have to have prior knowlege of what ID fields are supported.

In general, if the client wants to set some kind of user-writable ID, generally we'd use the Context property, similar to how Subscription works.

So, I checked the redfish spec and could not find anything about POST not allowing for setting 'Id' property. We just need to guarantee that it is unique across the collection of given resource. And the user of redfish api needs to know that it must be unique. There is also a fragment that we can ignore its user-set value if needed. But I don't think that we really need to ignore it, let me explain:
 
The Trigger URI will be /redfish/v1/TelemetryService/Triggers/{TriggerId} and should be stored in 'Location' header of message returned by POST request. Redfish spec says 'The identifier term in the URI pattern shall match the Id string property for the corresponding Resource'.

If user want to set 'Id' - I would allow it, and just return messages::resourceAlreadyExists in case it is already used. If not passed - it will be set by the service. And this is what I meant as 'optional', because once GET will be implemented, it will be always returned, as it is required for this resource.

Id is also not modifiable, so this way we limit user-writability to creation of resource. There will be no way to change it in the lifetime of resource by PATCH. 

This way we won't create any additional properties and everything will still be compatible with DMTF schemas.

A quick search returned this from section 7.9 of the spec regarding POST(create).

"The service may ignore any service controlled properties, such as Id , which would force the service to overwrite those properties."

This says that ID is "service controlled" which means the user shouldn't be able to set it.  Also, you make a good point, that the user could easily select an ID that conflicts with other members.

> "The service may ignore any service controlled properties, such as Id , which would force the service to overwrite those properties."

Yeah, it was exactly what I was referencing in previous comment. It also says that it 'may' be ignored. So if user sets it properly, I see no reason to ignore it.

In the same section we also have:
"The POST operation shall not be idempotent."
Which means that subsequent identical POST calls may yield different result (like when user tries to add same ID twice), so as long as we detect repeated ID, I think we are still compliant with spec.
Sure, that seems reasonable.
Ack

Shouldn't this be "starts_with"?

now that we have the latest version of boost::uri, we should ideally be comparing something like

url = parse_relative_uri(uri)

Then comparing segments

With that said, this would be the first use of that in bmcweb, so it's not neccesarily required.
I rewrote this function, and now it is way simpler.
note that this is a dbus utility function, not a URL utility function.  You ideally should be using boost::uri, then using url::segments[3] and url::segments[4]

I am aware of that, but url_view::segments is not yet in the boost.url version used by bmcweb.
I tried to update it locally, but it seems to be a little tricky as it is depending on latest development version of boost (which is newer than current 1.77 release).

I am more than eager to do this the proper way, when it will be possible.

if this is something you're interested in, check out this series:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/48297
Ack
?  Why is this neccesary?

Given following MetricProperty: /redfish/v1/Chassis/AC_Baseboard/Thermal#/Fans/0/Reading
we except chassis = "AC_Baseboard" and node = "Thermal", to further process them in dbus<->uri mapper.
Ah, I see now;  We really need to get a real uri parser in here, because that code is really hard to understand.
Done
Doesn't this need to return some kind of error?

This function name suggest it is converting already validated redfish name to dbus name. And this is the only Action which differs - the rest are named the same on dbus.

And... while I was writing this comment I found out that I do not validate user input for Action. I will add another method to keep it clean 😊

> This function name suggest it is converting already validated redfish name to dbus name. And this is the only Action which differs - the rest are named the same on dbus.
> 
> And... while I was writing this comment I found out that I do not validate user input for Action. I will add another method to keep it clean 😊

Even in the cases where they're the same, I'd like to see us be consistent, because they could potentially change or get added to in the future.  It looks like you found the issue I was really pointing out though, in that we're not validating the users input here.

So I was thinking about using boost bidirectional map, or maybe just simple constexpr std::array of std::pair. This will allow to convert it both ways in case of GET method. Would such implementation be acceptable?
Both of those take more code, are slower, and more memory.  Please just write if/else ladders for each, as that's what we do other places.
Understood, fixed in latest patchset.
Why the sub structs here?  Seems like neither are used in isolation, so the don't need to be separate structs?

My intention was to separate fields to create logical and readable hierarchy

dbusArgs - used to store params passed during AddTrigger dbus call

parsedInfo - used to store information provided by user, which are not directly passed on dbus, but might be usable during parse and validation of other params.

Yes, there might be incredibly slight overhead due to memory alignment, but it is nearly negligible, when compared to improved readability of code.

Generally these "convert redfish type to dbus type" operations return a string or a std::optional<string>  Passing a context object in to fill makes the method more difficult to reason about.  Lets follow the pattern we've used other places.
Done - for this function and getDiscreteTriggerCondition.
Done

This method takes no ownership of ctx in this case, this can be passed by Context&

This is true of a number of other methods in this patchset.  Please fix all of them.
Done

Please don't construct what are essentially static maps like this just to do lookups on them.  use a struct if that's what you want to do.

Said another way, I see no use of numericThresholdsMap.find() in the code below, and the operator[] could easily be replaced with struct members.

I would like to leave this flat_map here, because in the line 123 I am using this to loop over both key and value. 

According do redfish spec, "NumericThresholds" is complex type which contains up to 4 properties (UpperCritical, LowerCriticall, etc.) and all of those properties are objects of same type. While struct could be used here, this would decrease readability of code, and would require creation of additional helper method, which would need to be called 4 times, for each struct.

For now I can improve this fragment by removing the initialization (lines 105-108), as the optional() would be created by operator [] in lines 112-115 anyway. Of course reserve() will be called 😊

But if you insist, I can remove this map altogether, but it just seems a little wrong for me.
init your variables please
Done
all 3 of these params are required in the standard?

This is good question. By redfish schemas there are only two required properties for the whole Trigger resource: Id and Name.

I found in .yaml schema that those 3 fields are 'nullable' - does this mean that they are not required? Or am I missing any other docs?

From Telemetry Service backend it just doesn't make much sense for them to not be required. There is just no way for us to deduce those values and they must be passed.

For now I would leave them as required, and I will research more about this.
Good use of an already existing helper method.
Ack
This looks like it was designed to avoid the warning that std::milliseconds uses int64_t and this code uses uint64_t.  I suspect we need to align our types here.
DwellTime cannot be negative, so this is why we are passing uint64 over dbus. I don't know if this can be improved here. Or did I misunderstood you? What can be done otherwise to align the types?
on line 120, could parsedParams just be a reference to ctx->dbusArgs.thresholds?
ctx.dbusArgs.thresholds is a variant of two different vectors, and getting reference to it, while possible is not much helpful. But there is other improvement possible - std::move()
if this check were inverted, it would save a scope for the code below.
Done
This method is explicitly called out by name in COMMON_ERRORS.md.  Please read and understand those rules.
Done
Same comment as above, lets avoid the copy.
As above (thresholds is a variant), I think it would be better to use std::move()
prefer range based for here if i is only used as an index.
Done
Shouldn't this also be vector<nlohmann::json> ?
numeric thresholds is an object of up to 4 properties.
See above, this can be removed.
Ack
Sure!
Thanks for suggestion, this seems like it could improve readability, and will be similar to other getX functions.
Done
This follows the same thing, where the api is a little tough to determine the behavior of.  Again, I think an enum class here would help quite a bit.
Ack

In all code paths it looks like this just gets loaded into ctx.dbusArgs.thresholds.  Could this instead be a reference, and avoid the moves entirely?  Something like

std::vector<NumericThresholdParams>& parsedParams; ctx.dbusArgs.thresholds;

Please read these directly into a struct with 4 members, or possibly a std::array of size 4 if that makes the loop below cleaner.  This pattern of using operator[] on a map directly in line with a readJson call has some undefined behavior that's very difficult to trace down when it occurs, and definitely has UB here, as map references are potentially invalidated whenever the map is modified, which happens 4 times in the course of calling this function.  Said another way, the reference to numericThresholdsMap["UpperCritical"] will be invalidated when the call to numericThresholdsMap["LowerCritical"] is done.

NumericThresholds is very unusual case, due to it being an object with multiple optional keys, where each of them is referencing same complex type, I thinks this function needs a small refactor.

I decided to not use readJson in this particular case - this way we can loop directly over key/values of json. There are just two additional checks that must be made: if the numericThresholds json is an object, and if its keys are correctly named. It looks way cleaner and seems to be slightly faster, as there no additional structs/arrays or maps.

I will push it with latest patchset, but if you insist, I can easily rewrite it again to use struct/array solution.
nit: This doesn't look right.  You reserve of size numericThresholds.size(), then loop over numericThresholdsMap.

numericThresholds will always have between 0 and 4 keys. The map always have 4 keys, but some of them may stay std::nullopt - and line 110 is checking this. So emplace_back will always be called the same number of times as the size used during reservation.

But after refactor, which I described in above comment, this will look more clear.

This is converting an int64_t based time into a uint64_t based time.  Does this need range checked, or instead, should we use std::duration_cast<std::duration<uint64_t, std::milli>> to do this conversion?
I am working on overflow-safe helper, which might be useful here, but its not finished and tested yet. I will let you know once I have something.
Same comment as above, could this be a referernce.
See my comment above
missing const.  Please just declare this explicitly as const nlohmann::json&.

Can't be const as readJson is expecting non-const reference.
I managed to modify it to use const reference, please take a look here: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/48763

Should be using duration cast.  This happens often enough (I think there's two other places we have to do this in code today) and is confusing enough that it might be worth having a helper function to encapsulate this?  the other uses are for EnterDwellTimeSeconds and ExitDwellTimeSeconds
I am working on overflow-safe helper, which might be useful here, but its not finished and tested yet. I will let you know once I have something.

Generally when we do things like this, instead of constructing an int, we construct an object with something useful in the destructor.  This ensures that even if exceptions are thrown, or the call count has behavior issues, we can still run the final result.
I reused Finalizer class idea from the past. I can include it in other similar cases in bmcweb (like MetricReportDefinition), if approved here.
are this two used in this commit?
triggerUri is used. I just moved them from trigger.hpp for consistency, but for some reason diff is not showing it - maybe due to rebase?
Ok, I found it. Both of them are used.
You should add condition to check if current resp status is ok. Otherwise you may add report even if something already failed.
Done
Ready for review. Closed comments which were already fixed. I also shifted refactor part to other change for easier review.
